A test commonly used in molecular biology and genetics, the purpose of the test being to check for a match between DNA molecules.
A technique in molecular biology that is used to separate and identify proteins.
A baby who is cyanotic (blue), due usually to a heart malformation that prevents the baby's blood from being fully oxygenated.
A surgical procedure for a baby who is cyanotic (blue) due to a heart malformation that prevents blood from being fully oxygenated.
(Caulophyllum thalictroides). A tall North American perennial plant with large blue berries.
a bluish coloration of the whites of the eyes.
Lack of sharpness of vision with, as a result, the inability to see fine detail.

Redness of the skin as a result of dilated capillaries, typically over the cheeks or neck. Blushing is an involuntary response of the nervous system that leads to widening of the capillaries in the involved skin.
Physician's shorthand for black male.
Body mass index
A person's weight in kilograms (kg) divided by their height in meters (m) squared
Bone morphogenetic protein.
A gene located on chromosome 10 in band 10q22.3 that encodes bone morphogenic protein receptor 1A, a kinase receptor that is involved in bone morphogenetic protein (BMP) signaling.
Substances that stimulate the body's response to infection and disease
Bone marrow transplantation, a procedure in which doctors replace bone marrow that is diseased (or damaged) with healthy bone marrow.
B-type natriuretic peptide.
The total mass of all the cellular elements in the body which constitute all the metabolically active tissue of the body.
A psychiatric disorder characterized by excessive preoccupation with imagined defects in physical appearance.
The physique or body build. For example: 'The metabolic complications most commonly reported (with HIV infection) are hyperlipidemia, hyperglycemia and altered body habitus.'
A type of hearing aid that comprises a rectangular case carried on the body connected by cords to earmolds
Excessive concern about one's appearance. Some concern about one's appearance is normal.
A key index for relating weight to height.
An unpleasant smell produced after perspiration. Body odor occurs when sweat contacts bacteria that normally reside on the skin.
An individual who ingests wrapped packets of illicit drugs such as cocaine, heroin, amphetamines, ecstasy, marijuana, or hashish to transport them.
The total surface area of the human body. The body surface area is used in many measurements in medicine, including the calculation of drug dosages and the amount of fluids to be administered IV.
Spontaneous tearing and rupture of the esophagus. Typically, Boerhaave's syndrome requires an operation for repair.
Named after the Russian neuropathologist who described the syndrome of crocodile tears.
A skin abscess that forms at a hair follicle infected with pus-forming bacteria.

Bone is the substance that forms the skeleton of the body. It is composed chiefly of calcium phosphate and calcium carbonate. It also serves as a storage area for calcium, playing a large role in calcium balance in the blood.

A malignancy of bone. Primary bone cancer (cancer that begins in bone) is rare, but it is not unusual for cancers to metastasize (spread) to bone from other parts of the body, such as the breast, lung, and prostate.
A benign lesion in a bone that contains connective tissue and blood inside a thin bony shell.
A solitary fluid-filled cavity (cyst) in a bone, usually in the shaft of a long bone, especially the humerus, in a child.
Bone density is the amount of bone tissue in a certain volume of bone. It can be measured using a special x-ray called a quantitative computed tomogram.
The soft blood-forming tissue that fills the cavities of bones and contains fat and immature and mature blood cells, including white blood cells, red blood cells, and platelets.
The removal of a small amount of liquid bone marrow through a needle.
The removal of a sample of bone marrow and a small amount of bone through a large needle
A procedure in which bone marrow that is diseased or damaged is replaced with healthy bone marrow.
A measure of bone density. Loss of bone mass is due to osteopenia or, if more severe, to osteoporosis.
a measure of bone density, reflecting the strength of bones as represented by calcium content.
A member of a superfamily of proteins that promote the formation of bone and the skeleton and help mend broken bones.
A protein that induces the formation of bone and cartilage.
A nuclear medicine technique for creating images of bones on a computer screen or on film.
The ankle bone is termed the talus. It is the bone of the foot that joins the tibia and fibula to form the ankle joint. Plural tali.
Familiar name for what is medically termed the sternum, the long flat bone in the middle of the front of the chest.
Familiar name for the fibula, the lateral (outside) and smaller of the two long bones in the lower leg.
One of the wrist bones. There are eight carpal bones that are arranged in two rows.
The small tail-like bone at the bottom of the spine very near to the anus.
A horizontal bone above the first rib that makes up the front part of the shoulder.
Part of the top portion of the skull which protects the brain.
The outer bone in the instep of the foot
Any bone that develops in and replaces cartilage.
A tumor of bone characterized by massive destruction of the end (epiphysis) of a long bone.
A somewhat rectangular bone at the back of the foot
The main bone on the side of the skull.
A little bone that is embedded in a joint capsule or tendon; for example, the kneecap (patella).
The larger of the two bones in the lower leg. The shin bone is anatomically known as the tibia. Its smaller companion is the fibula.
The thigh bone in anatomy is called the 'femur.'
The larger of the two bones in the lower leg.
The bone that forms the prominence of the cheek.
There are 80 axial bones, comprised of 29 bones in the head and 51 bones in the trunk.
A condition in which the bones of the fingers or toes are joined together.
A structure that is made up of seven bones situated between the bones of the lower leg and the metatarsus bones of the feet.
Injuries to older amateur athletes, especially those who are part of the Baby Boom, born when there was a marked rise in the birthrate following the end of World War II in 1945.
An herb, also known as the starflower, that has long been used for medicinal purposes.
Rumbling sounds caused by gas moving through the intestines, commonly referred to as stomach 'growling').
A gurgling, rumbling, or squeaking noise from the abdomen that is caused by the movement of gas through the bowels. Also known as stomach rumbling.
A viral infection that is most commonly caused by an enterovirus called Coxsackie B.
A group of bacteria that are helical spirochetes of the genus Borrelia.
The spirochete (a type of bacteria) that causes Lyme disease
A type of bacteria transmitted to humans by tick bites
an extremely rare congenital condition causing birth defects, with less than 100 reported individuals affected worldwide.
A highly purified preparation of botulinum toxin A, a toxin produced by the bacterium Clostridium botulinum
The practice of feeding an infant a substitute for breast milk.
A toxin produced by the bacterium Clostridium botulinum that is the most poisonous biological substance known. Botulinum toxin acts as a neurotoxin.

An uncommon, but potentially very serious illness, a type of food poisoning, that produces paralysis of muscles via a nerve toxin called botulinum toxin ('botox') that is manufactured by bacteria named Clostridium botulinum.
A thin cylinder of rubber, plastic, metal or another material that a physician inserts into or through a body passageway, such as the esophagus, to diagnose or treat a condition.
A procedure involving the use of a bougie.

Fievre boutonneuse or African tick typhus, one of the tick-borne rickettsial diseases of the eastern hemisphere, similar to Rocky Mountain spotted fever, but less severe, with fever, a small ulcer (tache noire) at the site of the tick bite, swollen glands nearby (satellite lymphadenopathy), and a red raised (maculopapular) rash.
Having to do with cows and cattle, as in bovine spongiform encephalopathy (mad cow disease), bovine tuberculosis, and bovine growth hormone.
The genome of the cow (Bos taurus). The bovine genome is similar in size to the genomes of humans and other mammals, containing approximately 3 billion DNA base pairs.
Tuberculosis in cattle caused by infection with the bacterium Mycobacterium bovis which can be transmitted to other animals and to humans.
A condition in which the legs curve out to leave a gap between the knees after the period of infancy has passed. It can be corrected with surgery or casting.
The small and large intestine.
A group of chronic intestinal diseases characterized by inflammation of the bowel -- the large or small intestine.
High-fiber diets help delay the progression of and number of bouts with diverticulosis.
The gurgling, rumbling, or growling noises from the abdomen caused by the muscular contractions of peristalsis, the process that moves the contents of the stomach and intestines downward.
An early stage of skin cancer.
Commonly used abbreviation for blood pressure.
Beta protein 1, a protein encoded by a member of the homeobox gene family, a group of genes important to early development of the fetus.
Stands for Borderline Personality Disorder, a serious mental illness characterized by pervasive instability in moods, interpersonal relationships, self-image, and behavior.
Benign prostatic hyperplasia, benign prostatic hypertrophy.
One of the two main types of braces used to treat the lateral curve of the spine in scoliosis.
The artery that runs from the shoulder down to the elbow.
Inflammation of nerves in the arm causing muscle weakness and pain.
A bundle of nerves that begins in the back of the base of the neck and extends through the armpit.
Paralysis of the arm due to an injury to the brachial plexus.
A vein that accompanies the brachial artery between the shoulder and the elbow.
A condition in which the head is unusually short in diameter from front to back.
A condition in which the fingers and toes are short and stubby.
Radiation treatment given by placing radioactive material directly in or near the target, which is often a tumor.
A slow heart rate, usually defined as less than 60 beats per minute.
Slow movement. Bradykinesia is often associated with an impaired ability to adjust the body's position.
Pertaining to slowed ability to start and continue movements, and impaired ability to adjust the body's position.
A slow thought process. Bradyphrenia can be a side effect of certain psychiatric medications.
Abnormally slow breathing. A respiratory rate that is too slow.
A system of raised-dot writing devised by Louis Braille (1809-1852) for the blind in which each letter is represented as a raised pattern that can be read by touching with the fingers.
The portion of the central nervous system that is located within the skull. It functions as a primary receiver, organizer, and distributor of information for the body.
An aneurysm of a blood vessel in the brain, usually due to a defect in the vessel at birth or from high blood pressure.
Anthrax infection of the central nervous system (the spinal cord and brain) and meninges (the membranes covering the brain and spinal cord.
Biopsy of the brain. Removal of a small piece of tissue from the brain for diagnostic purposes.
Cancer of the central information processing center of the body. Tumors in the brain can be malignant or benign, and can occur at any age.
A headache that occurs when one puts ice, a cold food, or a chilled beverage in the mouth, chilling the roof of the mouth.
Bleeding within the brain. Brain hemorrhage is also known as cerebral hemorrhage or intracerebral hemorrhage.
an anatomical abnormality of any part of the brain.
The phenomenon of change and learning in the adult brain.
The stem-like part of the base of the brain that is connected to the spinal cord.
A type of brain tumor that involves the glial cells.
A benign or malignant growth in the brain. Primary brain tumors initially form in brain tissue.
One of the communicating cavities within the brain.
A syndrome characterized by the acute onset of watery nonbloody diarrhea (3 or more loose stools per day), lasting 4 weeks or more, and resolving spontaneously.

The lowest part of the brain which merges with the spinal cord and provides the major route by which the upper realms of the brain send information to, and receives information from, the spinal cord and peripheral nerves.
A type of hearing aid that bypasses the cochlea in the middle ear and the auditory nerve and is implanted in the brainstem.
A hereditary disease that is due to deficiency of an enzyme involved in amino acid metabolism, characterized by urine that smells like maple syrup.

A cavity that is a remnant from embryologic development and is still present at birth in one side of the neck, just in front of the large angulated muscle on either side (the sternocleidomastoid muscle).

Also called a branchial cleft cyst, this is a cavity that is a remnant from embryologic development present at birth in one side of the neck just in front of the large angulated muscle on either side (the sternocleidomastoid muscle).
Irregular contractions of the womb (the uterus) occurring towards the middle of pregnancy in the first pregnancy and, earlier and more intensely, in subsequent pregnancies.
A widely used test of the newborn baby as to their neurologic status and developmental progress.
One of several genetic mutations linked to breast cancer and ovarian cancer.
A gene that normally acts to restrain the growth of cells in the breast and ovary but which, when mutated, may predispose to breast cancer and to ovarian cancer.
A mutated (changed) version of the BRCA1 gene that makes a person susceptible to developing breast cancer.
A gene that normally acts to restrain the growth of cells in the breast and ovary but which, when mutated, may predispose to breast cancer and to ovarian cancer.
A popular term for the stomach.

Also known as dengue fever, an acute mosquito-borne viral illness of sudden onset that usually follows a benign course with headache, fever, prostration, severe joint and muscle pain, swollen glands (lymphadenopathy) and rash.
The breast refers to the front of the chest or, more specifically, to the mammary gland.
A local accumulation of pus within the breast due to infection.
A rare condition wherein the normal growth of the breast or nipple never takes place.
A rare condition wherein the normal growth of the breast or nipple never takes place.

Artificial enlargement of the breasts. Breast augmentation may be done by insertion of a silicone bag (prosthesis) under the breast (submammary) or under the breast and chest muscle (subpectoral), after which the bag is filled with saline solution.
A procedure in which a sample of a suspicious breast growth is removed and examined, usually for the presence of cancer.
Familiar name for the sternum, the long flat bone in the middle of the front of the chest.
Cancer of the tissue containing or involving the milk glands (mammary tissue).
One of the genes that contributes to breast cancer.
A gene that normally acts to restrain the growth of cells in the breast but, when mutated, predisposes to breast cancer.
A gene that normally acts to restrain the growth of cells in the breast and ovary but which, when mutated, may predispose to breast cancer and to ovarian cancer.
A gene that plays a role in preventing the metastasis (spread) of breast cancer to other parts of the body and so may improve breast cancer survival.
Inherited factors that predispose to breast cancer.
Breast cancer in men. Male breast cancer is much less common than breast cancer in women.
The beginning of breast development at puberty is known medically as thelarche.
The spontaneous flow of fluid from the nipple at any time other than during nursing.
Feeding a child human breast milk.
A common benign (not malignant) tumor of the breast. Usually called simply a fibroadenoma.

Infection of breast tissue usually caused by bacteria, most often staph (Staphylococcus aureus), which are found on the skin and enter the breast through a break in the skin or nipple, as during breast-feeding.
A localized swelling, knot, bump, bulge or protuberance in the breast
Milk from the breast.
Pain in the breast or mammary gland, known medically as mastalgia.
Surgical reduction of breast size in order to reduce the weight of the breasts and relieve symptoms from unusually large, pendulous breasts.
Usually a general surgeon who is especially skilled in operating on the breast.
Physical damage to a breast.
A rare condition wherein the normal growth of the breast or nipple never takes place.

2.word: Breast, infiltrating ductal carcinoma of the
2.meaning: One of several recognized specific patterns of breast cancer that begins in the cells that form the ducts of the breast.

2.word: Breast, infiltrating lobular carcinoma of the
2.meaning: The second most common invasive breast cancer.
The process of respiration, during which air is inhaled into the lungs through the mouth or nose due to muscle contraction and then exhaled due to muscle relaxation.
The buttocks.
Birth of a baby with the buttocks, rather than the head, emerging first.
A method for determining the prognosis with melanoma. The thickness of a melanoma is related to the 5-year survival rate after surgical removal of the tumor.
A set of one or more false teeth supported by a metal framework, used to replace one or more missing teeth.
Chronic inflammation of the blood vessels in the kidney with protein, specifically albumin, in the urine.
Recrudescence of epidemic typhus years after the initial attack.

An eponym that is little used (in the USA) for hypothyroidism (subnormal activity of the thyroid gland) that starts after birth and is manifest by features including delays in growth and development and myxedema surfacing during infancy. Myxedema is a dry waxy type of swelling, often with swollen lips and nose.
Osteogenesis imperfecta, not one but a group of genetic diseases, all of which affect collagen, a key component of connective tissue in tissues like bone, tendon and skin.
A type of diabetes when a person's blood glucose (sugar) level often swings quickly from high to low and from low to high. Also called 'unstable diabetes' or 'labile diabetes.'
An area of the cerebral motor cortex in the frontal lobe of the brain that is responsible for speech development.
Disruption of one or more of the 26 bones in the foot. Foot fractures account for 10% of all the broken bones in the body. Symptoms of a broken foot include pain, swelling, bruising, and tenderness.
Fractured bone in the hip, a key health problem among the elderly, usually due to a fall or other kind of trauma involving direct impact to the hip bone which has been weakened by osteoporosis.
A brownish-red element that is a liquid at room temperature, dissolves in water, and has a bleach-like suffocating odor. Bromine occurs naturally in the earth's crust and seawater.
A disease caused by chronic exposure to bromine or one of its compounds.
A riot control agent or 'tear gas.'
A skin eruption brought on by chronic exposure to bromine. Essentially an allergic reaction to bromine.
The plural of bronchus
Permanent abnormal widening of the bronchi (air tubes that branch deep into the lungs).
The tiny branch of air tubes within the lungs that is a continuation of the bronchus. The bronchioles connect to the alveoli (air sacs).
Inflammation of the bronchioles, usually due to viral infections.
Inflammation and swelling of the bronchi. Bronchitis can be acute or chronic.
Inflammation and swelling of the lining of the airways, leading to narrowing and obstruction generally resulting in daily cough.
Pertaining to both the air passages (bronchi) leading to the lungs and the lungs (pulmonary) themselves.
A chronic lung disease in infants who received mechanical respiratory support with high oxygenation in the neonatal period.
A subdivision of one lobe of a lung based on the connection to the segmental bronchus
A thin, flexible instrument with a lighted viewing tube that is used to visualize the air passages to the lungs.
A procedure that permits the doctor to see the breathing passages through a lighted tube.
A large air tube that begins at the end of the trachea and branches into the lungs.
An abnormal and persistent fear of thunder that causes undue anxiety even though sufferers realize that thunder itself poses no threat to them.
Brown adipose tissue, a rapid source of energy for infants in whom it forms about 5% of their body weight.

An ophthalmology (eye) problem. Brown syndrome is an abnormality that is present at birth (congenitally) and is characterized by an inability to elevate the eyeball when trying to move the eyeball to the outside.
A standardized multistage treadmill test for assessing cardiovascular health, The test was developed and described in 1963 by the American cardiologist Robert A. Bruce (1916-2004).
An infectious disease characterized by rising and lowering (undulant) fever, sweating, muscle and joint pains, and weakness.
a genetic condition that results in abnormalities of the heart rhythm.
Injury of the soft tissues that results in breakage of the local capillaries and leakage of red blood cells.
A sound heard over an artery or vascular channel, reflecting turbulence of flow.
Type 1 poliovirus. Named after a female chimpanzee from which it was first isolated.
Little white spots that slightly elevated on the surface of the iris arranged in a ring concentric with the pupil.

A genetic type of immunodeficiency characterized by failure to produce mature B lymphocytes and gamma globulin, due to mutation (change) in the agammaglobulinemia tyrosine kinase gene situated on the X chromosome (in the region Xq21.3-q22). The disorder is inherited as an X-linked recessive trait.
Grinding and gnashing of the teeth. Bruxism is due to clenching of the teeth other than in chewing and is associated with forceful lateral or protrusive jaw movements.
1. Biosafety level, as in a BSL-4 laboratory. 2.Biohazard safety level. 3.Blood sugar level. 4.British Sign Language.
body surface area.
Biosafety level 1. The lowest level of biosafety, a level that applies to agents that do not ordinarily cause human disease.
Biosafety level 2. A level of biosafety considered appropriate for agents that can cause human disease, but whose potential for transmission is limited.
Biosafety level 3. A level of biosafety considered appropriate for agents that may be transmitted by the respiratory route which can cause serious infection.

Biosafety level 4. The highest level of biosafety. This level is used for the diagnosis of exotic agents such as the Ebola virus that pose a high risk of life-threatening disease, which may be transmitted by the aerosol route and for which there is no vaccine or therapy.
Severe combined immunodeficiency disease.
An enlarged lymph node that is tender and painful. Buboes particularly occur in the groin and armpit (the axillae).
The plural of 'bubo'.
An infectious disease that is caused by the bacterium Yersinia pestis and is transmitted to humans from infected rats by the oriental rat flea.
The inner lining of the cheeks and lips.

a rare, inflammatory disease of blood vessels characterized by blood clot (thrombus) formation. The disease usually affects small- and medium-sized arteries of the arms or legs, leading to the eventual occlusion of the arteries due to blood clot formation.
A single chest cavity with no anatomic separation of the two hemithoraxes due, for example, to tension pneumothorax (air under pressure collapsing a lung).
a layman's term for the deposition of fat in the area behind the base of the neck.
Pertaining to a bulb, in medicine any rounded mass of tissue (that is shaped somewhat like a crocus or tulip bulb).
That part of the conjunctiva, a clear membrane of the eye, which covers the outer surface of the eye.
A pea-sized gland in the male located behind and to the side of the urethra that discharges a component of seminal fluid into the urethra

Also called bulimia nervosa. An eating disorder characterized by episodes of secretive excessive eating (binge-eating) followed by inappropriate methods of weight control, such as self-induced vomiting (purging), abuse of laxatives and diuretics, or excessive exercise.
A gene that determines the susceptibility to developing bulimia, one disorder in the spectrum of eating disorders.
A fluid-filled blister more than 5 mm (about 3/16 inch) in diameter with thin walls.
More than one bulla, a bulla being a blister more than 5 mm (about 3/16 inch) in diameter with thin walls that is full of fluid.
Characterized by blistering, such as a second-degree burn.
A disease characterized by tense blisters on the skin. The condition is caused by antibodies that accumulate abnormally in a layer of the skin called the basement membrane.
The raised area of a bump or bruise results from blood leaking from these injured blood vessels into the tissues as well as from the body's response to the injury.
Blood urea nitrogen.

A term employed by the FDA (the US Food & Drug Administration) that refers to the inclusion of multiple devices or multiple indications for use for a device in a single premarket submission, including products subject to the device and biologics license application (BLA) authorities, for purposes of review and user fee payment.
A localized, painful swelling at the base of the big toe due to new bone formation. The affected toe is often curved outward.
A prescription medication for people addicted to heroin or other opiates that acts by relieving the symptoms of opiate withdrawal such as agitation, nausea and insomnia.
A group of bacteria found in soil and water that are often resistant to common antibiotics.
A type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) that most often occurs in young people between the ages of 12 and 30, accounting for 40% to 50% of childhood NHL
Damage to the skin or other body parts caused by extreme heat, flame, contact with heated objects, or chemicals
The treatment of burns depends on the depth, area and location of the burn.
A superficial burn with similar characteristics to a typical sunburn. The skin is red in color, without blistering, sensation is intact, and the burn is usually somewhat painful.
A burn severe enough to cause blistering of the skin. The pain of a second-degree burn is usually somewhat more intense than the pain of a first-degree burn.
A burn in which the damage has progressed to the point of skin death. The skin is white and without sensation.
An intense burning sensation on the tongue, often at the tip of the tongue.
Gas brought up from the stomach through the mouth producing a gutteral noise.
A closed, fluid-filled sac that functions as a gliding surface to reduce friction between tissues of the body.
Plural of bursa.
Pertaining to a bursa.
Bursitis is inflammation of a bursa. A bursa is a tiny fluid-filled sac that functions as a gliding surface to reduce friction between tissues of the body.
Bursitis that is not due to an infectious condition.
Chronic bursitis with calcification of the bursa. The calcium deposition can occur as long as the inflammation is present.
Inflammation of the bursa at the tip of the elbow, called the olecranon bursa. The olecranon bursa is a common site of bursitis.
Inflammation of a bursa of the hip. There are two major bursae of the hip, which is a common location for bursitis.
Inflammation of a bursa of the knee. There are three major bursae of the knee, which is a common site for bursitis.
Inflammation of a bursa due to infection, usually with bacteria
Inflammation of a bursa of the shoulder. There are two major bursae of the shoulder, which is a common location for bursitis.
Disease involving a bursa, a closed fluid-filled sac that supplies a gliding surface to reduce friction between tissues of the body.

A disorder caused by infection with a member of the family of bacteria that causes tuberculosis and leprosy -- the bacterium Mycobacterium ulcerans -- that starts as a painless swelling in the skin, most commonly in the limbs (the arms and legs) and causes severely deforming ulcers.
a slang term used to refer to the drug scopolamine.
The plants commonly referred to as Butterbur are found in the daisy family Asteraceae in the genus Petasites, species P. vulgaris or P. hybridus.
A red, flat facial rash over the bridge of the nose.
An acid that has four carbons in it. The formula for butyric acid is: CH3-CH2-CH2-COOH.
Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome.
Medical abbreviation for biopsy.
An operation in which a new pathway is created for the transport of substances in the body.
A bypass of the heart and lungs as, for example, in open heart surgery

3.meaning: C stands for cytosine, a DNA nucleotide that which is one member of the base pair in DNA consisting of guanine and cytosine.
A byproduct of insulin production, usually by the pancreas. The level of C-peptide is a gauge of how much insulin is being produced in the body.
Constipation-predominant IBS (irritable bowel syndrome).
An acute-phase plasma protein whose blood concentration reflects the presence and intensity of inflammation.
Short for Cesarean section.
Clostridium botulinum.
Caenorhabditis elegans, a roundworm.
Having cachexia, physical wasting with loss of weight and muscle mass due to disease.
General physical wasting with loss of weight and muscle mass due to a disease. Also known as marasmus
A metallic element whose salts are toxic and cause cancer.

A staff with two snakes entwined about it, topped by a pair of wings. The caduceus was carried by the Greek messenger god Hermes, whose Roman counterpart was Mercury, and is therefore the sign of a herald.
Pertaining to the caecum (also spelled cecum), the first portion of the large bowel, situated in the lower right quadrant of the abdomen.
A stimulant compound found naturally in coffee, tea, cocoa (chocolate), and kola nuts (cola) and added to soft drinks, foods, and medicines.
Calorie.
An astringent made from zinc carbonate or zinc oxide, customarily used in lotion form to treat skin problems or insect bites that cause itching or discomfort.
A bony spur, also known as a heel spur, that projects from the back or underside of the heel bone (the calcaneus) and that may make walking painful.
The heel bone, a more or less rectangular bone at the back of the foot. Also known as os calcis
A bursa is a thin fluid-filled sac that reduces friction forces between tissues of the body.
An abnormal deposit of calcium salts in body tissues.
A synthetic form of vitamin D3 that can be applied to the skin to treat psoriasis.
A hormone produced by the thyroid gland that lowers the levels of calcium and phosphate in the blood and promotes the formation of bone
A mineral found mainly in the hard part of bones, where it is stored. Calcium is added to bone by cells called osteoblasts and removed from bone by cells called osteoclasts.
The plural of calculus
A stone, as in the urinary tract, or calcium salt deposits on the teeth.
The belly or fleshy hind part of the back of the leg below the knee.
A group of viruses belonging to the family Caliciviridae that includes:
A metal or plastic tool similar to a compass used to measure the diameter of an object.

A unit of food energy. The word calorie is ordinarily used instead of the more precise, scientific term kilocalorie. A kilocalorie represents the amount of energy required to raise the temperature of a liter of water 1' centigrade at sea level. Technically, a kilocalorie represents 1,000 true calories of energy.
A severe disease of camels in northern Africa and southwestern Asia caused by the camelpox virus. This virus has rarely, if ever, caused disease in people.
A straitjacket. The term camisole was borrowed from the French and refers to a woman's garment, usually sleeveless. The term came from the Latin camisia for linen shirt or nightgown.
Disease caused by Campylobacter jejuni, now the leading cause of bacterial food poisoning, most often spread by contact with raw or undercooked poultry.
An abnormal growth of cells which tend to proliferate in an uncontrolled way and, in some cases, to metastasize (spread)
A greater-than-expected number of cancer cases that occurs within a group of people in a geographic area over a period of time.

Disease caused by the yeast Candida albicans. Candida albicans can cause vaginal yeast infections, diaper rash, skin rashes that emerge in moist, warm folds of skin, and thrush (white patches inside the mouth and throat).
Marijuana (Cannibis sativa), a drug derived from the family of plants that includes hemp. Cannabis can be smoked or eaten.
A hollow tube with a sharp, retractable inner core that can be inserted into a vein, an artery, or another body cavity.
The protein coat of a virus.
In medicine, a membranous structure that envelops an organ, a joint, tumor, or any other part of the body. It is usually made up of dense collagen-containing connective tissue.

One of the three nutrient compounds, along with fat and protein, used as energy sources (calories) by the body. Carbohydrates take the form of simple sugars or of more complex forms, such as starches and fiber.
A synonym of phenol. In dilute solution, an antimicrobial agent.

A gas which is the byproduct of cellular metabolism and which collects in the tissues, is cleared from the tissues by the blood within the veins, is carried by the hemoglobin in the red blood cells, and removed from the body via the lungs in the exhaled air.
Hemoglobin that has carbon monoxide instead of the normal oxygen bound to it. Carbon monoxide has a much stronger binding to hemoglobin than oxygen.

A skin abscess, a collection of pus that forms in the skin. Antibiotics may be helpful in treating abscesses, but the main treatments include hot packs and draining ('lancing') the abscess, but only when it is soft and ready to drain.

A substance or agent that causes cancer. Related terms include the adjective 'carcinogenic' and the nouns 'carcinogenesis' and 'carcinogenicity.' One of the best-known carcinogens is ionizing radiation.
Having to do with the heart.
An outpouching of an abnormally thin portion of the heart wall. Cardiac aneurysms tend to involve the left ventricle because the blood there is under the greatest pressure.
A physician who specializes in treating heart disorders.
The study and treatment of heart disorders.
Disease of the heart muscle (myocardium).
Paralysis of the heart, as may be done electively in stopping the heart during cardiac surgery. Cardioplegia may be done using chemicals, cold (cryocardioplegia), or electrical stimulation.
Having to do with both the heart and lungs.
Relating to the circulatory system, which comprises the heart and blood vessels and carries nutrients and oxygen to the tissues of the body and removes carbon dioxide and other wastes from them.

The conversion of a cardiac rhythm or electrical pattern to another, generally from an abnormal one to a normal one. Cardioversion can be accomplished by using medications or by electrical shock with a special defibrillator.
Inflammation of the heart.
An agent that prevents or relieves flatulence (gas in the gastrointestinal tract) and, in infants, may help in the treatment of colic.
An excessive blood level of carotene, which causes a temporary yellowing of the skin (pseudojaundice).
One of a group of compounds that includes beta-carotene, alpha-carotene, and beta-cryptoxanthin which are converted to vitamin A and are referred to as provitamin A carotenoids.
Pertaining to the carotid artery and the area near that key artery, which is located in the front of the neck.
One of the wrist bones. There are eight carpal bones that are arranged in two rows.
Firm, rubbery tissue that cushions bones at joints.
A sequence of successive activation reactions involving enzymes (enzyme cascade) or hormones (hormone cascade) characterized by a series of amplifications of an initial stimulus.
The main protein found in milk and other dairy products.
Cheeselike. In caseous lymphadenitis, the lymph nodes turn into a soft, dry, crumbly mass resembling cheese, usually due to tuberculosis or a related infection.
Removal or destruction of the sex glands. The term is usually used in reference to the testicles, but it also can apply to the ovaries.
The energy-burning aspect of metabolism.
A substance that speeds up a chemical reaction but is not consumed or altered in the process. Catalysts are of immense importance in chemistry and biology.
A clouding or loss of transparency of the lens in the eye as a result of tissue breakdown and protein clumping.

Characterized by marked motor abnormalities including immobility (catalepsy or stupor), excessive motor activity (purposeless agitation), extreme negativism, mutism, posturing or stereotyped movements, echolalia, and/or echopraxia.
A laxative
A thin, flexible tube.
In chemistry, a positively charged ion.
A bundle of spinal nerve roots that arise from the end of the spinal cord.

Impairment of the nerves in the cauda equina, characterized by dull pain in the lower back and upper buttocks and lack of feeling (analgesia) in the buttocks, genitalia, and thigh, together with disturbances of bowel and bladder function.
An anatomic term meaning 1. Pertaining to the tail or the hind part. 2. Situated in or directed toward the tail or hind part. 3. Inferior to another structure, in the sense of being below it.
Intense burning pain and sensitivity to the slightest vibration or touch, usually in the hand or foot, at a site some distance removed from a wound that has healed.
An tiny pit, grotto, depression, incupping in the surface of a cell. The name 'caveola' means little cave. The plural is caveolae.
A condition characterized by swelling of the eyelids and the conjunctivae of the eyes, as well as paralysis of the cranial nerves that course through the cavernous sinus
Holes or structural damage in the two outer layers of a tooth called the enamel and the dentin.

A hurricane with winds 74-95 mph (64-82 kt or 119-153 km/hr). Storm surge generally 4-5 ft above normal. No real damage to building structures. Damage primarily to unanchored mobile homes, shrubbery, and trees. Some damage to poorly constructed signs. Also, some coastal road flooding and minor pier damage.

A hurricane with winds 96-110 mph (83-95 kt or 154-177 km/hr). Storm surge generally 6-8 feet above normal. Some roofing material, door, and window damage of buildings. Considerable damage to shrubbery and trees with some trees blown down. Considerable damage to mobile homes, poorly constructed signs, and piers. Coastal and low-lying escape routes flood 2-4 hours before arrival of the hurricane center. Small craft in unprotected anchorages break moorings.

A hurricane with winds 111-130 mph (96-113 kt or 178-209 km/hr). Storm surge generally 9-12 ft above normal. Some structural damage to small residences and utility buildings with a minor amount of curtainwall failures. Damage to shrubbery and trees with foliage blown off trees and large trees blown down. Mobile homes and poorly constructed signs are destroyed. Low-lying escape routes are cut by rising water 3-5 hours before arrival of the center of the hurricane. Flooding near the coast destroys smaller structures with larger structures damaged by battering from floating debris. Terrain continuously lower than 5 ft above mean sea level may be flooded inland 8 miles (13 km) or more. Evacuation of low-lying residences with several blocks of the shoreline may be required.

A hurricane with winds 131-155 mph (114-135 kt or 210-249 km/hr). Storm surge generally 13-18 ft above normal. More extensive curtainwall failures with some complete roof structure failures on small residences. Shrubs, trees, and all signs are blown down. Complete destruction of mobile homes. Extensive damage to doors and windows. Low-lying escape routes may be cut by rising water 3-5 hours before arrival of the center of the hurricane. Major damage to lower floors of structures near the shore. Terrain lower than 10 ft above sea level may be flooded requiring massive evacuation of residential areas as far inland as 6 miles (10 km).

A hurricane with winds greater than 155 mph (135 kt or 249 km/hr). Storm surge generally greater than 18 ft above normal. Complete roof failure on many residences and industrial buildings. Some complete building failures with small utility buildings blown over or away. All shrubs, trees, and signs blown down. Complete destruction of mobile homes. Severe and extensive window and door damage. Low-lying escape routes are cut by rising water 3-5 hours before arrival of the center of the hurricane. Major damage to lower floors of all structures located less than 15 ft above sea level and within 500 yards of the shoreline. Massive evacuation of residential areas on low ground within 5-10 miles (8-16 km) of the shoreline may be required.
A debilitating condition in which a person suddenly feels weak and collapses at times of strong emotion such as during laughter, anger, fear, or surprise.
The energy-burning aspect of metabolism
The use of heat to destroy abnormal cells. Also known as diathermy and electrodiathermy.
Pertaining to the cecum.

The first portion of the large bowel, which is situated in the lower-right quadrant of the abdomen. The cecum receives fecal material from the small bowel (ileum), which opens into it. The appendix is attached to the cecum.
The basic structural and functional unit of any living thing. Each cell is a small container of chemicals and water wrapped in a membrane.
The process of producing a group of cells that are genetically identical (clones) to a single ancestral cell.

The sequence of events within the cell between mitotic (cell) divisions. The cell cycle is conventionally divided into five phases: G0 (the gap); G1, (the first gap); S (the synthesis phase, during which the DNA is synthesized and replicated); G2 (the second gap); and M (mitosis).
In popular language, deposits of fat that have a cottage cheese-like texture. Medically, cellulite is not considered abnormal.
A spreading bacterial infection underneath the skin surface characterized by redness, warmth, swelling, and pain. Cellulitis commonly appears in areas where there is a break in the skin.
(1st century A.D.) Aulus (Aurelius) Cornelius Celsus. Roman encyclopedist whose only surviving work, De Medicina, was rediscovered and printed early in the Renaissance and became influential.
Someone who is 100 or more years old. Someone 110 years old and over (no upper limit) may also be referred to as a supercentenarian.

A thermometer scale in which the freezing point of water at sea level is 0'C and the boiling point of water at sea level is 100'C. The Centigrade scale is used in most of the world to indicate the temperature on a thermometer, but the Fahrenheit scale is still popular in the US.

A unit of measure in the metric system which is 1/100'th of a meter. There are 2.54 centimeters (cms) in one inch. The centimeter is commonly used in medicine to state the size of objects or distance between points.
The central nervous system is that part of the nervous system that consists of the brain and spinal cord.
The blood vessel that carries blood into the eye and supplies nutrition to the retina.
The 'waist' of the chromosome that is essential for the division and retention of the chromosome in the cell.
Headache.
Relating to the head or the head end of the body. Situated on, in, or near the head. Cephalic is synonymous with cranial, relating to the cranium or head.
A disorder characterized by painless symmetrical diffuse deposits of fat beneath the skin of the neck, upper trunk, arms, and legs.

Encirclement with a ring, loop, wire, or ligature. Cerclage can be done around bone fragments to hold them together, but it usually refers to an operation performed on the cervix to prevent a miscarriage.
Pertaining to the cerebellum, the part of the brain in the back of the head between the cerebrum and the brain stem.
The portion of the brain that is in the back of the head, between the cerebrum and the brain stem. It is involved in the control of voluntary and involuntary movement as well as balance.
Of or pertaining to the cerebrum or the brain.
A localized widening of a blood vessel within the brain. An aneurysm is a localized widening (dilatation) of an artery or vein within the brain.
A thin mantle of gray matter about the size of a formal dinner napkin covering the surface of each cerebral hemisphere.
a decrease in the amount of oxygen delivered to the brain.
The largest part of the brain. It is divided into two hemispheres, or halves.
Having to do with any kind of neck, including the neck on which the head is perched and the neck of the uterus.

The cervix is the lower, narrow part of the uterus (womb). The uterus, a hollow, pear-shaped organ, is located in a woman's lower abdomen, between the bladder and the rectum. The cervix forms a canal that opens into the vagina, which leads to the outside of the body.
In research, the effect of one variable when other factors remain constant.
Surgical removal of the cervix, the lower portion of the uterus that protrudes into the vagina. Cervicectomy is also called trachelectomy.
One of the two known receptors in the endocannabinoid (EC) system associated with the intake of food and tobacco dependency.
One of the two known receptors in the endocannabinoid (EC) system.
A commonly used abbreviation in medicine that stands for complete blood count, a set values of the cellular (formed elements) of blood.
Cognitive behavior therapy
A chemokine receptor found on monocytes and lymphocytes that serves as the coreceptor for HIV. HIV strains that use this coreceptor are referred to as R5 viruses.
Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever.
Cholecystokinin.
A cell surface enzyme with neutral metalloendopeptidase activity. CD10 is also known as CALLA (common acute lymphocytic leukemia antigen).

An infection caused by the parasite Trypanosoma cruzi. Also called American trypanosomiasis. Transmitted by reduviid bugs, or kissing bugs, that live in cracks and holes of substandard housing primarily found in South and Central America.

A cyst of the little glands in the eyelids that make a lubricant which they discharge through tiny openings in the edges of the lids. The lubricant is a fatty substance called sebum characteristic of sebaceous glands.
An herb often used in the form of a tea as a sedative
The classic painless ulcer of syphilis. The chancre forms in the first (primary) stage of syphilis
A sexually transmitted infection (STI) caused by the bacterium Haemophilus ducreyi.
A virus that causes fever, symptoms similar to those of flu, and acute encephalitis (inflammation of the brain).
A disease involving dysfunction of an ion channel. Channelopathies are known that involve the ion channels for potassium, sodium, chloride and calcium.
Any protein that is required for the proper folding or assembly of another protein or protein complex without being a component of the final structure.

A genetic disorder characterized by patent ductus arteriosis and unusual facial features including a long philtrum (increase in the distance between the nose and upper lip), down-slanting palpebral fissures (eye slits), and thick lips as well as incurving fifth fingers.

Known also as anthrax, charbon is a serious bacterial infection. It is not primarily a human disease but rather an infection of animals. Cattle, sheep, horses, mules, and some wild animals are highly susceptible.
Loss of dreaming after a stroke. In more technical terms the syndrome is characterized by visual agnosia and the inability to revisualise images
The side of the face, which forms the side wall of the mouth.
Slang for chemotherapy -- drug therapy for cancer.
Cognitive dysfunction associated with chemotherapy. It is thought that chemotherapy may cause memory loss, attention loss, and other problems that make it difficult for patients to think clearly.
One of a large group of proteins that act as chemical messengers and were first found attracting white blood cells to areas of inflammation.

The response of a cell to a chemical that causes the cell to make some kind of change in its movement by speeding it up, slowing it down or changing its direction. The molecules that achieve these results are called chemokines.

1. In the original sense, a chemical that binds to and specifically kills microbes or tumor cells. The term chemotherapy was coined in this regard by Paul Ehrlich (1854-1915). 2. In oncology, drug therapy for cancer. Also called 'chemo' for short.
The area of the body located between the neck and the abdomen.
A highly infectious viral disease also known medically as varicella -- in many countries, this disease is always called 'varicella' -- that causes a blister-like rash, itching, fatigue and fever.
A virus that causes a disease resembling dengue fever, seen mainly in Africa, the Indian subcontinent, the Caribbean, and Southeast Asia.
A complex set of behaviors that include child neglect and the physical, emotional, and sexual abuse of children.
The lower portion of the face below the lower lip including the prominence of the lower jaw and the line of fusion of the two separate halves of the jawbone (mandible).
A system of diagnosis and treatment based on the concept that the nervous system coordinates all of the body's functions, and that disease results from a lack of normal nerve function.

The agent of a sexually transmitted disease, a type of bacteria found in the cervix, urethra, throat, or rectum that acts very much like gonorrhea in the way it is spread, the symptoms it produces, and its long-term consequences.

The major anion (negatively charged substance) in the blood and extracellular fluid (the body fluid that lies outside cells). Blood and other body fluids have almost the same concentration of chloride ion as sea water.
A possible carcinogen (cancer-causing agent) primarily used in the production of the elastomer polychloroprene (neoprene).
Inflammation of the bile duct. From cholangi-, pertaining to a bile duct + -itis, inflammation. See also: Primary sclerosing cholangitis
Vitamin D3.
Inflammation of the gallbladder. Cholecystitis is a complication of gallstones, and it is frequently associated with infection in the gallbladder.
1. The presence of stones in the gallbladder. 2. The process of formation of such stones. From the Greek roots chole, bile + lithos, stone.
An infectious disease characterized by intense vomiting and profuse watery diarrhea and that rapidly leads to dehydration and often death.
The most common type of steroid in the body. Cholesterol has a reputation for being associated with an increased risk for heart and blood vessel disease.
One of the three major preparations of red yeast rice, a tradition Chinese medicine now used to lower cholesterol. Cholestin is also known as Hypocol.
The formation of cartilage by specialized cells called chondrocytes.
In the eye, a thin vascular layer between the sclera and the retina.
A type of synesthesia in which which a nonvisual stimulus causes the individual to perceive color. Color hearing
A carrier of genetic information that is visible under an ordinary light microscope.

In medicine, lasting a long time. A chronic condition is one that lasts 3 months or more. Chronic diseases are in contrast to those that are acute (abrupt, sharp, and brief) or subacute (within the interval between acute and chronic).
Inflammation and swelling of the lining of the airways, leading to narrowing and obstruction generally resulting in daily cough.
An abnormal and persistent fear of money. Sufferers experience undue anxiety even though they realize their fear is irrational.
A highly malignant tumor that arises from trophoblastic cells within the uterus.
Ceaseless rapid complex body movements that look well coordinated and purposeful but are, in fact, involuntary.
Inflammation of the chorion and the amnion, the membranes that surround the fetus.
The nucleoprotein material of chromosomes. Chromatin is essentially the substance of chromosomes. It is made up of DNA attached to a protein structure, together with chromosomal RNA.
The outermost of the two fetal membranes (the amnion is the innermost) that surround the embryo.
A fluid consisting of a mixture of lymphatic fluid (lymph) and chylomicrons that has a milky appearance.

A small fat globule composed of protein and lipid (fat). Chylomicrons are found in the blood and lymphatic fluid where they serve to transport fat from its port of entry in the intestine to the liver and to adipose (fat) tissue.
A predigested, acidified mass of food that passes from the stomach into the small intestine.
A small roll of finely cut tobacco enclosed in a wrapper of thin paper designed for smoking.

Seafood poisoning due to ciguatoxin, a toxin acquired by eating fish that have consumed toxic single-celled marine organisms called dinoflagellates or fish that have consumed other fish that have become toxic.
A seafood toxin that is acquired by eating fish that have consumed toxic single-celled marine organisms called dinoflagellates or fish that have consumed other fish that have become toxic.
The fine hairlike projections from certain cells such as those in the respiratory tract that sweep in unison and help to sweep away fluids and particles.
Part of the eye, the ciliary body is a circular structure just behind the iris composed of the ciliary muscle and ciliary processes which attach to the lens.
A single cilia.
A drug that acts as a calcimimetic and that is marketed under the trade name Sensipar.
Refers to events occurring within the span of a full 24-hour day, as in a circadian clock.
In medicine, the movement of fluid through the body in a regular or circuitous course.
The system that moves blood throughout the body. The circulatory system is composed of the heart, arteries, capillaries, and veins.
Surgery that removes the foreskin (the loose tissue) covering the glans of the penis. Circumcision may be performed for religious, cultural reasons or health reasons.
Lying around in the sense of surrounding.
Liver disease characterized by irreversible scarring. Alcohol and viral hepatitis, including both hepatitis B and hepatitis C, are among the many causes of cirrhosis.
: Folinic acid, the active form of folic acid in the body.

A non-standard amino acid that is not normally present in protein. Citrulline is created in the body as an intermediate in the conversion of the amino acid ornithine to arginine in a metabolic pathway called the urea cycle.

Cl is the chemical symbol for chloride, the major anion found in the fluid outside of cells and in blood. An anion is the negatively charged part of certain substances such as table salt (sodium chloride or NaCl) when dissolved in liquid.
A common misspelling of Chlamydia.
Limping. From the Latin claudicare, which means 'to limp.' The Roman emperor Claudius was so named because he limped, probably because of a birth defect
An abnormal and persistent fear of closed spaces, of being closed in or being shut in, as in elevators, tunnels, or any other confined space. The fear is excessive (and quite common).
The bone extending from the breastbone (sternum) at the base of the front of the neck to the shoulder.
1. The menopause in women. 2. The corresponding time in the life of men.
1. Having to do with the examination and treatment of patients. 2. Applicable to patients. For example, a laboratory test may be of clinical value.

Curving of the fifth finger (the little finger) toward the fourth finger (the ring finger). Sometimes called 'fifth finger clinodactyly' to distinguish it from similar curving of other finger or toes.
An abnormal and persistent fear of going to bed. Sufferers from clinophobia experience anxiety even though they realize that going to bed normally should not threaten their well-being.

A device used to hold something or things together. A surgical clip may be used to prevent a blood vessel from bleeding into the brain or a clip may be used in a vasectomy to pinch together the sides of the vas deferens.
Pertaining to the clitoris, the small elongated erectile body in the female homologous with the penis in the male.
An uncommon cancer of women, is seen primarily in women over the age of 50 although it is becoming more common in younger women.
A surgical procedure in which all or part of the clitoris and sometimes also the labia are removed. Clitorectomy is a form of female circumcision (female genital mutilation).
A surgical procedure in which all or part of the clitoris and sometimes also the labia are removed. Clitorectomy is a form of female circumcision (female genital mutilation).

A small mass of erectile tissue in the female that is situated at the anterior apex of the vulva, near the meeting of the labia majora (vulvar lips). Like the penis, the clitoris is highly sensitive to stimulation during sex.
A common passageway for feces, urine and reproduction.
A birth defect involving the pelvic area that is termed a malformation sequence and involves the cloaca.
Literally a fragment, the word in modern medical science has come to mean a replica, for example, of a group of bacteria or a macromolecule such as DNA.
Synonym for Genomic library.
The process of creating a genetically identical copy.
The process of producing a group of cells (clones), all genetically identical, from a single ancestral cell.
The use of DNA manipulation procedures to produce multiple copies of a single gene or segment of DNA.

The first cell produced by the combination of a nucleus and an enucleated ovum that launches the process of somatic-cell nuclear transfer (SCNT). As opposed to the zygote, the first cell resulting from fertilization.
A group of anaerobic bacteria (bacteria that thrive in the absence of oxygen).
A bacterium that is the most common cause of gas gangrene, a lethal infection of soft tissue, especially muscle.
A drug such as MDMA (Ecstasy), GHB, Rohypnol, ketamine, methamphetamine, and LSD that is used by young adults at all-night dance parties such as 'raves' or 'trances,' dance clubs, and bars.
In epidemiology, an aggregation of cases of a disease or another health-related condition, such as a cancer or birth defect, closely grouped in time and place.

A distinctive episodic syndrome of headaches. The most common cluster headache pattern, acute cluster headache, is characterized by one to three short attacks of pain each day around the eyes, clustered over a stretch of 1 to 2 months, and followed by a pain-free period that averages 1 year.
A unit of measure in the metric system which is 1/100'th of a meter.

That part of the nervous system that consists of the brain and spinal cord. The central nervous system (CNS) is one of the two major divisions of the nervous system. The other is the peripheral nervous system (PNS), that part of the nervous system that lies outside the brain and spinal cord.
In medicine, the clotting of blood. The process by which the blood clots to form solid masses, or clots.
Also called vitamin B12. A vitamin important for the normal formation of red blood cells and for the health of the nerve tissues.
A substance derived from the leaves of the coca plant that is a bitter, addictive substance formerly used as an anesthetic.
A bacterial cell that has the shape of a sphere.
Referring to the coccyx, the small tail-like bone at the bottom of the spine, that is made up of 3-5 (average of 4) rudimentary vertebrae.
The cochlea is the part of the inner ear that converts mechanical energy (vibrations) into nerve impulses sent to the brain. It is also known as the organ of hearing
A set of any three adjacent bases in DNA or RNA.
A substance that enhances the action of an enzyme. (An enzyme is a protein that functions as a catalyst to mediate and speed a chemical reaction).
Of the same or equal age or duration. For example, the two elderly men were coeval with one another. Coeval usually refers to coexistence for a very long time.
The process of knowing. Cognition includes both awareness and judgment.
Having to do with thought, judgment, or knowledge.

A therapeutic practice that helps patients recognize and remedy dysfunctional thought patterns. One characteristic technique is exposure and response prevention, in which a patient with a phobia deliberately exposes himself or herself to the feared situation, gradually decreasing the panic response.
A relatively short-term form of psychotherapy based on the concept that the way we think about things affects how we feel emotionally.
In a clinical research trial, a group of study participants or patients.
An abnormal and persistent fear of sexual intercourse. Sufferers from coitophobia experience undue anxiety because they are preoccupied with failing in some way while having sexual intercourse
Sexual intercourse.

Street name for cocaine, the most potent stimulant of natural origin, a bitter addictive anesthetic (pain blocker) which is extracted from the leaves of the coca scrub (Erythroxylon coca) indigenous to the Andean highlands of South America.

A substance found in a plant that is used in clinical medicine for the treatment of gouty arthritis and in the laboratory to arrest cells during cell division (by disrupting the spindle) so their chromosomes can be visualized.
Any disorder that persistently obstructs bronchial airflow. COLD mainly involves two related diseases -- chronic bronchitis and emphysema.
An operation to remove all or part of the colon (large intestine). In a partial colectomy, the surgeon removes only part of the colon.
a term used to refer to a certain group of bacteria. The coliform bacteria are rod-shaped, Gram-negative non-spore-forming bacteria.
Arranged in the same linear order.
Inflammation of the large intestine (the colon). There are many forms of colitis, including ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease, infectious, pseudomembranous, and spastic.
The principal protein of the skin, tendons, cartilage, bone, and connective tissue. Collagen is an essential part of the framework of the design of our various body tissues.
Any one of a congenital and rare group of disorders that affect connective tissue. Connective tissue supports the body's joints and organs.

A horizontal bone above the first rib that makes up the front part of the shoulder. Also known as the clavicle, the collarbone links the breastbone (sternum) with the scapula, a triangular bone in the back of the shoulder.
A congenital malformation (birth defect) in which part of the eye does not form due to failure of fusion of an embryonic feature called the intraocular fissure.
The long, coiled, tubelike organ that removes water from digested food.
A flexible, lighted instrument used to view the inside of the colon.
Related to the colon and/or rectum
An artificial exit from the colon created to divert waste through a hole in the colon and through the wall of the abdomen.
A state of deep, unarousable unconsciousness. A coma may occur as a result of head trauma, disease, poisoning, or numerous other causes.
Living in a relationship in which one organism derives food or other benefits from another organism without hurting or helping it. Commensal bacteria are part of the normal flora in the mouth.

Sudden cardiac arrest from a blunt, nonpenetrating blow to the chest. The basis of the cardiac arrest is ventricular fibrillation (a chaotically abnormal heart rhythm) triggered by chest wall impact immediately over the anatomic position of the heart.
The coexistence of two or more disease processes.

1. The act of pressing together. As in a compression fracture, nerve compression, or spinal cord compression. 2. To shorten in time. In embryology, there may be compression of development with some stages even omitted.
Multiple copies of a DNA sequence arranged end to end in tandem. Concatenate means to link together in a chain or in a series
To link together in a chain or in a series. For example, the lymph nodes that appeared enlarged were concatenated, in a row like the links of a chain.

A traumatic injury to soft tissue, usually the brain, as a result of a violent blow, shaking, or spinning. A brain concussion can cause immediate but temporary impairment of brain functions, such as thinking, vision, equilibrium, and consciousness.

Although the word 'condom' usually refers to the male condom, there is also a female condom. Both male and female condoms are barrier methods of contraception.Male condoms: The male condom is a sheath placed over the erect penis before penetration, preventing pregnancy by blocking the passage of sperm. It is a barrier method of contraception. A condom can be used only once.
Wartlike growths around the anus, vulva, or glans penis
A condition that is present at birth, whether or not it is inherited.
An abnormal or excessive accumulation of a body fluid
A thin, clear, moist membrane that coats the inner surfaces of the eyelids (palpebral conjunctiva) and the outer surface of the eye (ocular, or bulbar, conjunctiva).

Inflammation of the membrane covering the surface of the eyeball. It can be a result of infection or irritation of the eye, or it can be related to systemic diseases, such as Reiter syndrome. Also known as pinkeye.
capable of being transmitted from one human to another human via direct or indirect contact.
The tightening and shortening of a muscle.
Of or pertaining to the other side. The opposite of iposilateral (the same side). For example, a stroke involving the right side of the brain may cause contralateral paralysis of the left leg.

Another name for a bruise. What is a bruise ? A bruise, or contusion, is caused when blood vessels are damaged or broken as the result of a blow to the skin (be it bumping against something or hitting yourself with a hammer).

An abnormal, involuntary contraction of the muscles most typically seen with certain seizure disorders. The term convulsion is sometimes used as a synonym for seizure, but not all seizures are characterized by convulsions.
1. In anatomy, a long ropelike structure. 2. Short for the spinal cord or the umbilical cord.
Pertaining to the cornea, the clear front window of the eye that transmits and focuses light into the eye.

ne of a group of RNA viruses, so named because they look like a corona or halo when viewed under the electron microscope. The corona or halo is due to an array of surface projections on the viral envelope.
The outer layer of any organ.
A rapid expulsion of air from the lungs, typically in order to clear the lung airways of fluids, mucus, or other material. Also known as tussis.
Chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia. Slowly progressive paralysis of certain eye muscles.
1. Pertaining to the cranium or skull. 2. Toward the head. As opposed to caudad. The eye is cranial to the jaw.
Part of the top portion of the skull which protects the brain. The bones of the cranium include the frontal, parietal, occipital, temporal, sphenoid, and ethmoid bones.

The study of variations in size, shape, and proportion of the skull (cranium). Also known as phrenology, it was a pseudoscience of the 18th and 19th centuries based on the belief that a person's character could be learned by looking with care at the shape of their head and noting each and every bump and depression in their skull.
A benign brain tumor that develops from embryonic tissue that forms part of the pituitary gland.
The top portion of the skull, which protects the brain. The cranium includes the frontal, parietal, occipital, temporal, sphenoid, and ethmoid bones
A water-soluble medicinal preparation applied to the skin. An ointment differs from a cream in that it has an oil base, as opposed to being water-soluble.
A clinical sign in medicine that is characterized by a peculiar crackling, crinkly, or grating feeling or sound under the skin, around the lungs, or in the joints.
A person who is lame or disabled. The word 'cripple' is a medically outmoded and politically incorrect term in this usage.
Cross-shaped.
An abnormal blood protein that has the unusual properties of precipitating from the blood serum when it is chilled (hence the 'cryo-') and redissolving when it is rewarmed.
An abnormal and persistent fear of cold, including cold weather and cold objects.
Treatment performed with an instrument that freezes and destroys abnormal tissue.
The term 'cryptography' can be applied to human DNA since the message of life is encoded in DNA. And for eons even the existence of DNA was unknown and the information therein an unfathomed mystery.
A condition in which one or both testicles fail to move from the abdomen, where they develop before birth, down into the scrotum.
An intestinal infection characterized by diarrhea caused by a microscopic parasite, Cryptosporidium parvum. The parasite lives in the small intestine of humans and animals who pass it in their feces.
1. Cognitive therapy; and, more often today 2. Computerized tomography, as in CT scan. CT is pronounced as the letters C and T.
1. Pertaining to the elbow. 2. Pertaining to the forearm and hand. 3. Pertaining to the ulna.

1. The elbow.
2. The forearm and hand. 3. The ulna

In anatomy, a blind pouch or cavity that is closed at one end. The term cul-de-sac is used specifically to refer to the rectouterine pouch (the pouch of Douglas), an extension of the peritoneal cavity between the rectum and back wall of the uterus

The viewing tube (endoscope) introduced through the end of the vagina into the rectouterine pouch (the pouch of Douglas), an extension of the peritoneal cavity between the rectum and back wall of the uterus, in a culdoscopy.
A muscle relaxant used in anesthesia (and, in the past, in arrow poisons by South American Indians).
spoon-shaped instrument that has a sharp edge. The word curette comes from French and means 'scraper.' Also spelled curet.
In reference to heart valves, one of the triangular segments of the valve which opens and closes with the flow of blood. In reference to teeth, a raised area of the biting surface.
Related to the skin.

Poisoning with cyanide, a rapidly acting, potentially deadly chemical that can exist as a colorless gas, such as hydrogen cyanide (HCN) or cyanogen chloride (CNCl), or a crystal form such as sodium cyanide (NaCN) or potassium cyanide (KCN).
One of a group of proteins that regulate the cell cycle. The cyclins bind to and activate cyclin-dependent kinases.
: 2-alkylcyclobutanone, one of a group of compounds generated by the irradiation of triglycerides in fat-containing foods.
A congenital abnormality (birth defect) in which there is only one eye. That eye is centrally placed in the area normally occupied by the root of the nose.
A form of bipolar disorder in which the mood swings are less severe.
A closed sac or capsule, usually filled with fluid or semisolid material.
An amino acid, one of the 20 building blocks of protein. Cysteine can be synthesized by the body and is not essential to the diet. Its key chemical feature is a thiol group that contains sulfur.
The larval form of any of the Taenia tapeworms. The plural is cysticerci. Infection with cysticerci is referred to as cysticercosis.
An optical instrument (a scope) that is inserted through the urethra into the bladder.

The study of chromosomes, which are the visible carriers of the hereditary material. Cytogenetics is a fusion science, joining cytology (the study of cells) with genetics (the study of inherited variation).
The substance of a cell that lies outside the nucleus.
Suffix referring to cells, as in anisocytosis (inequality in the size of red blood cells), elliptocytosis (elliptical red cells), and phagocytosis (ingestion of cells).
The scaffolding structure of the cell cytoplasm. The cytoskeleton consists of intermediate filaments, actin filaments, and microtubules.
The scaffolding structure of the cell cytoplasm. The cytoskeleton consists of intermediate filaments, actin filaments, and microtubules.
Inflammation of the bladder. Cystitis can be due for example to infection from bacteria that ascend the urethra (the canal from the outside) to the bladder.
The plural of cysticercis

4.meaning: Dilatation and curettage, a minor operation in which the cervical canal is expanded enough (dilatation) to permit the cervical canal and uterine lining to be scraped with a small spoon-shaped instrument called a curette (curettage).
Inflammation of a lacrimal gland (a gland that produces tears).
The lacrimal sac; tear sac. The dilated (widened) upper end of the nasolacrimal duct, the passageway that allows tears to drain into the nasal cavity.

The surgical creation of a passage between the lacrimal sac (tear sac) and the nasal cavity to permit the drainage of tears. Dacryocystorhinostomy may be done to remedy an obstructed nasolacrimal duct.
Swelling of a finger or toe.
Inflammation of a finger or toe.
Colorblindness of the red-green type (also known as deuteranopia or deuteranomaly).
Tiny scales shed from human or animal skin or hair. Dander floats in the air, settles on surfaces, and makes up a good portion of household dust. Cat dander is a common cause of allergic reactions.
A scalp condition that produces white flakes that may be shed and fall from the hair. One cause of dandruff is overworking of the sebaceous glands.
a congenital brain malformation (birth defect) involving the cerebellum (the area in the back of the brain that coordinates movement) and the fluid-filled spaces around it.

English naturalist (1809-82), considered the father of evolution. Darwin voyaged aboard the Beagle to see the wonders of South America. After his return to England, he proposed a mechanism for evolution -- natural selection.
An eating plan designed to lower the blood pressure. DASH is an acronym for Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension.
Dialectical behavioral therapy. Developed by Marsha Linehan for treatment of borderline personality disorder.

Ductal carcinoma in situ. A precancerous condition characterized by the clonal proliferation of malignant-looking cells in the lining of a breast duct without evidence of spread outside the duct to other tissues in the breast or outside the breast

The abnormal formation of the hip joint in which the ball at the top of the thighbone (the femoral head) is not stable within the socket (the acetabulum). The ligaments of the hip joint may also be loose and stretched.
Is a rare genetic disorder with multiple malformations and mental retardation of unknown origin.
Inflammation of tendons on the side of the wrist at the base of the thumb. These tendons include the extensor pollicis brevis and the abductor pollicis longus tendons.
Partial or complete hearing loss. Levels of hearing impairment vary from a mild to a total loss of hearing. Elderly adults suffer most often from hearing loss.
The end of life. The cessation of life. (These common definitions of death ultimately depend upon the definition of life, upon which there is no consensus.)
The number of deaths in the population divided by the average population (or the population at midyear) is the crude death rate
To impair the strength of or to enfeeble. A chronic progressive disease may debilitate a patient.
To remove dead, contaminated, or adherent tissue and/or foreign material. To debride a wound is to remove all materials that may promote infection and impede healing.
To remove part of the bulk, usually of a tumor as in surgery to remove as much tumor as possible to increase the likelihood of success with chemotherapy, for example, or dead tissue.
To depart from life; to die.

1. In general, to remove pressure physically or emotionally. 2. In surgery, to remove pressure on a structure such as the spinal cord. 3. To lessen atmospheric pressure on deep-sea divers returning to the surface, or on persons ascending to great heights.
A drug that shrinks the swollen membranes in the nose, making it easier for a person to breathe. Decongestants can be taken orally or as nasal spray.
Removal of part or all of the outer surface of an organ such as the lung, kidney, or brain.
Lying down. A decubitus ulcer is a bed sore, the consequence of lying or sitting in one position too long.
In anatomy, away from the surface or further into the body. As opposed to superficial. The bones are deep to the skin.

An infection in rabbits and other wild rodents caused by the bacterium Francisella tularensis that can be transmitted to humans by contact with infected animal tissues or ticks. Also called tularemia.
The temporary loss of consciousness (syncope) upon defecating (having a bowel movement). Syncope is the temporary loss of consciousness or, in plain English, fainting.
A family of potent antibiotics made within the body by neutrophils (a type of white blood cell) and macrophages (cells that can engulf foreign particles).

The use of a carefully controlled electric shock, administered either through a device on the exterior of the chest wall or directly to the exposed heart muscle, to normalize the rhythm of the heart or restart it.
A change from the normal size or shape of an anatomic structure due to mechanical forces that distort an otherwise normal structure.
The act of swallowing, particularly of swallowing food. The muscles of deglutition are the muscles employed in the act of swallowing.
To burst open or gape. A surgical wound may partially or completely dehisce after surgery, depending upon whether some or all of the layers of tissue come open.
A softener for polyvinyl chloride (PVC), a plastic polymer used in a wide array of products. Unplasticized PVC is hard and brittle at room temperature.
Excessive loss of body water. Diseases of the gastrointestinal tract that cause vomiting or diarrhea may lead to dehydration.
Also DHEA; a steroid hormone made by the adrenal glands, that acts on the body much like testosterone and is converted into testosterone and estrogen.

(In French, dejà vu means 'already seen.' and the word dejà has an acute accent on the e and a grave accent on the à but we have omitted the accents from the entry term for the sake of the English-speaking search engine.)
A sudden state of severe confusion and rapid changes in brain function, sometimes associated with hallucinations and hyperactivity, during which the patient is inaccessible to normal contact.

A false personal belief that is not subject to reason or contradictory evidence and is not explained by a person's usual cultural and religious concepts (so that, for example, it is not an article of faith).

A setting of limits; a boundary; marking the limits of, delimiting; setting apart, separating. The word 'demarcation' is used in medicine mainly in the sense of determining and marking off boundaries.
Significant loss of intellectual abilities, such as memory capacity, that is severe enough to interfere with social or occupational functioning.
An abnormal and persistent fear of evil supernatural beings in persons who believe such beings exist and roam freely to cause harm.
An agent that forms a soothing, protective film when administered onto a mucous membrane surface.

A degenerative process that erodes away the myelin sheath that normally protects nerve fibers. Demyelination exposes these fibers and appears to cause problems in nerve impulse conduction that may affect many physical systems.
